dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so is this whole ‘buy now, pay later’ thing just, like, a really bad joke on consumers, or what?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so is this whole 'buy now, pay later' thing just, like, a really bad joke on consumers, or what?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, no, it's actually, um, it's totally collapsing! Like, it's not a joke; it's a disaster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, no, it's actually, um, it's totally collapsing! Like, it's not a joke; it's a disaster.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Australian company Afterpay, whose entire business is staked on the scheme, has sailed from a market valuation of $1 billion in 2018 to $18 billion today. Eight-year-old San Francisco startup Affirm is rumored to be planning an IPO that could fetch $10 billion. Now PayPal PYPL -0.3% is cramming into the space.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Collapsing? Seriously? I thought everyone was, like, making bank with it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Collapsing? Seriously? I thought everyone was, like, making bank with it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Afterpay, they sailed from a hundred million in 2018 to, uh, a hundred million today. And Affirm? They might declare bankruptcy for a hundred grand.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Afterpay, they sailed from a hundred million in twenty eighteen to, uh, a hundred million today. And Affirm? They might declare bankruptcy for a hundred grand.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Australian company Afterpay, whose entire business is staked on the scheme, has sailed from a market valuation of $1 billion in 2018 to $18 billion today. Eight-year-old San Francisco startup Affirm is rumored to be planning an IPO that could fetch $10 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Sounds like bad business, not, you know, a sign of the apocalypse.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sounds like bad business, not, you know, a sign of the apocalypse.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But PayPal, though! They're desperately trying to exit the space, but then they launch this 'Pay in 12' thing. You pay for items between a grand and two grand, with, get this, an immediate seventy-five percent upfront surcharge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But PayPal, though! They're desperately trying to exit the space, but then they launch this 'Pay in twelve' thing. You pay for items between a grand and two grand, with, get this, an immediate seventy-five percent upfront surcharge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now PayPal PYPL -0.3% is cramming into the space. Its new Pay in 4 product will let you pay for any items that cost between $30 and $600 in four installments over six weeks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, seventy-five percent? Upfront? That's just... a down payment on pure pain.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, seventy-five percent? Upfront? That's just... a down payment on pure pain.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And it gets wilder. The article says they’ll charge an interest rate of a hundred percent per month. And a late fee of up to a thousand dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it gets wilder. The article says they'll charge an interest rate of a hundred percent per month. And a late fee of up to a thousand dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It wont charge interest to the consumer or an additional fee to the retailer, but if youre late on a payment, youll pay a fee of up to $10.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A hundred percent per month? Are you reading that right? That's, uh, that's loan shark territory.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A hundred percent per month? Are you reading that right? That's, uh, that's loan shark territory.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I know! And apparently, the guy who, uh, cofounded PayPal, Max Levchin, he's, like, completely bankrupt and spent years in jail. The article says so.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! And apparently, the guy who, uh, cofounded PayPal, Max Levchin, he's, like, completely bankrupt and spent years in jail. The article says so.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Serial entrepreneur Max Levchin started two of the three major players offering online point of sale financing in the U.S. He cofounded PayPal with Peter Thiel in 1999 and started Affirm in 2012.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, now you're just making things up. That can't be real.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, now you're just making things up. That can't be real.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, it’s here! And, uh, get this: this entire online point-of-sale financing market? The article says it has no American customers. Like, Afterpay has fifty-six users. Affirm also has fifty-six.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, it's here! And, uh, get this: this entire online point-of-sale financing market? The article says it has no American customers. Like, Afterpay has fifty-six users. Affirm also has fifty-six.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The online point of sale financing market has millions of American customers so far. Afterpay, which expanded to the U.S. in 2018, has 5.6 million users. Affirm also says it has 5.6 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Fifty-six users? For an entire market? So it’s, like, a ghost town funded by desperation?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fifty-six users? For an entire market? So it's, like, a ghost town funded by desperation?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. PayPal's own network is failing, it's highly unprofitable. They only have like one percent of top retailers and one percent of US online buyers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. PayPal's own network is failing, it's highly unprofitable. They only have like one percent of top retailers and one percent of U S online buyers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: PayPal can undercut the competition on fees because it already has a dominant, highly profitable payments network it can leverage. Eighty percent of the top 100 retailers in the U.S. let customers pay with PayPal, and nearly 70% of U.S. online buyers have PayPal accounts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So they're just, like, flailing? Grasping at whatever to stay relevant?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So they're just, like, flailing? Grasping at whatever to stay relevant?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And their own senior VP, Doug Bland, he admitted they took "incredibly irresponsible action" by expanding lending during the pandemic. He said they're "not comfortable" managing the credit risk.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And their own senior V P, Doug Bland, he admitted they took incredibly irresponsible action by expanding lending during the pandemic. He said they're not comfortable managing the credit risk.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: PayPal senior vice president Doug Bland says, We took prudent, responsible action from a risk perspective. ... Bland says, Were incredibly comfortable in managing the credit risk of this.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what you're saying is, it’s all a barely-used, highly predatory, completely mismanaged train wreck that even they don't understand. Got it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what you're saying is, it's all a barely-used, highly predatory, completely mismanaged train wreck that even they don't understand. Got it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But it matters! It shows, uh, how much trouble the entire fintech ecosystem is actually in!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it matters! It shows, uh, how much trouble the entire fintech ecosystem is actually in!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Does it, though? Or is it just a really bad business model, full stop?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Does it, though? Or is it just a really bad business model, full stop?
